description: Scheduled task and cron job enumeration for privilege escalation and persistence detection

commands.name: List User Cron Jobs
commands.description: Display current user's cron jobs (scheduled tasks)

flag_explanations.-l: List - display current user's crontab entries

commands.notes:
Cron format:
minute hour day month weekday command.

OSCP tip:
Check if cron scripts are writable - modify to run reverse shell as cron user.

Time estimate:
<1 second.

Special strings:
@reboot (run at startup), @daily, @hourly, @weekly, @monthly.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Check other users' crontabs: crontab-user-specific Check system-wide crontab: crontab-system-wide Look for writable cron scripts: find /etc/cron* -type f -writable Check cron script permissions for privesc

commands.name: List Another User's Cron Jobs
commands.description: View cron jobs for a specific user (requires root privileges)

flag_explanations.sudo: Required to view other users' crontabs
flag_explanations.-u: Specify user whose crontab to display

commands.notes:
Root's crontab is high-value target.

If root cron runs writable script, instant privesc.

Crontab location varies:
/var/spool/cron/crontabs/ (Debian/Ubuntu), /var/spool/cron/ (RHEL/CentOS).

Time estimate:
<1 second.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Check root's crontab: sudo crontab -l -u root Check if cron scripts are writable by current user Replace script with malicious version if writable Wait for cron to execute for privilege escalation

commands.name: View System-Wide Crontab
commands.description: Display system-wide cron configuration (runs as root)
commands.notes:
/etc/crontab differs from user crontabs - includes username field.

Format:
minute hour day month weekday user command.

OSCP tip:
Check if PATH includes writable dirs like /tmp - allows command hijacking.

Time estimate:
<1 second.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Check cron directories: cron-directories-list Look for writable scripts called by cron Check PATH for writable directories (PATH hijacking)

commands.name: List Cron Directories
commands.description: List all cron directories (hourly, daily, weekly, monthly) and their contents

flag_explanations./etc/cron.*: Wildcard matches cron.hourly, cron.daily, cron.weekly, cron.monthly, cron.d

commands.notes:
Scripts in these directories run automatically:
cron.hourly (every hour), cron.daily (daily), cron.weekly (weekly), cron.monthly (monthly).

All run as root by default.

CRITICAL privesc vector if writable.

Time estimate:
2 seconds.

Command to find writable:
find /etc/cron* -type f -writable 2>/dev/null

methodology_guidance.after_success: Check file permissions: find /etc/cron* -type f -perm -o+w Check for writable scripts: find /etc/cron* -writable 2>/dev/null Modify writable script to add reverse shell

commands.name: View Recent Cron Executions
commands.description: Search system logs for recent cron job executions (verify cron activity)

flag_explanations.\"CRON\": Search pattern for cron log entries
flag_explanations./var/log/syslog: System log file (may be /var/log/messages on RHEL)

commands.notes:
Logs show when cron jobs execute and as which user.

Useful for timing privilege escalation attempts.

On systemd systems:
journalctl -u cron.

Time estimate:
3-5 seconds.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Identify frequently-run cron jobs Check execution times to plan privesc timing Look for failed cron jobs (potential misconfigurations) Monitor for new cron activity

commands.name: Windows List All Scheduled Tasks
commands.description: Display all Windows scheduled tasks with verbose details

flag_explanations./fo LIST: Format output as list (easier to read than table)
flag_explanations./v: Verbose - display detailed information including task actions, triggers, last run time

commands.notes:
CRITICAL for Windows privesc and persistence detection.

Output is verbose (20+ properties per task).

OSCP tips:
(1) Look for tasks with writable executables, (2) Tasks running as SYSTEM with Enabled status, (3) Custom tasks (non-Microsoft) in \Task Scheduler Library\.

Time estimate:
10-30 seconds depending on task count.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Look for tasks running as SYSTEM Check task executable paths for writable locations Identify custom (non-Microsoft) scheduled tasks Check task XML for credentials: Get task XML definition

commands.name: PowerShell List Scheduled Tasks
commands.description: PowerShell cmdlet to list enabled Windows scheduled tasks

flag_explanations.$_.State -ne \"Disabled\": Exclude disabled tasks (show only Ready/Running tasks)

commands.notes:
Modern PowerShell approach - faster and easier to parse than schtasks.

To see all tasks:
Get-ScheduledTask (no filter).

Time estimate:
5 seconds.

One-liner for custom tasks:
Get-ScheduledTask | Where-Object {$_.TaskPath -notlike '\Microsoft\*' -and $_.State -eq 'Ready'}

methodology_guidance.after_success: Get task details: win-ps-scheduled-task-info Filter non-Microsoft tasks: Where-Object {$_.TaskPath -notlike '\Microsoft\*'} Check task action/executable: Get-ScheduledTaskInfo Look for tasks with writable executables

commands.name: PowerShell Scheduled Task Details
commands.description: Get detailed information for specific scheduled task including last run time and result

flag_explanations.Get-ScheduledTaskInfo: Get additional info (last run time, last result, next run time)

commands.notes:
Useful for verifying task execution status.

LastTaskResult 0x0 = success, other values indicate errors.

Time estimate:
1 second.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Get task action: (Get-ScheduledTask -TaskName <TASK_NAME>).Actions Check executable path permissions: icacls <PATH> Export task XML: Export-ScheduledTask -TaskName <TASK_NAME> Modify task if writable: Set-ScheduledTask

commands.name: Export Scheduled Task XML
commands.description: Export scheduled task definition as XML (may contain credentials or sensitive data)

flag_explanations./xml: Output task definition in XML format (includes all configuration details)

failure_indicators: ERROR: The system cannot find the file specified
commands.notes:
XML may contain Base64-encoded credentials or sensitive command arguments.

Time estimate:
1 second.

Save to file:
schtasks /query /tn <TASK> /xml > task.xml

methodology_guidance.after_success: Search XML for credentials or sensitive data Check <Command> element for executable path Verify <UserId> to see which account runs task Check <Arguments> for command-line parameters

commands.name: WMIC AT Jobs (Legacy)
commands.description: List legacy AT jobs (older Windows scheduling system, pre-Task Scheduler)

flag_explanations.job: Query Win32_ScheduledJob WMI class (AT command jobs)

commands.notes:
AT jobs are legacy (Windows NT/2000 era), rarely used in modern systems.

Included for completeness in older OSCP labs.

Time estimate:
1 second.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Check command path permissions if jobs found Modern alternative: use schtasks or Get-ScheduledTask

commands.name: List Linux AT Jobs
commands.description: List pending AT jobs (one-time scheduled commands)
commands.notes:
AT is for one-time scheduled tasks (unlike cron for recurring).

Less common than cron.

View job:
at -c <JOB_ID>.

Time estimate:
<1 second.

methodology_guidance.after_success: View job details: at -c <JOB_ID> Remove job: atrm <JOB_ID> Check /var/spool/at/ for job files

commands.name: List systemd Timers
commands.description: List all systemd timers (modern Linux cron alternative)

flag_explanations.--all: Show all timers including inactive ones

commands.notes:
systemd timers are modern replacement for cron on systemd-based Linux.

Timers trigger .service units.

OSCP tip:
Check /etc/systemd/system/ for custom timers.

Time estimate:
2 seconds.

To see active only:
systemctl list-timers (no --all)

methodology_guidance.after_success: View timer details: systemctl cat <TIMER_NAME>.timer Check associated service: systemctl cat <TIMER_NAME>.service Look for writable timer or service files: ls -la /etc/systemd/system/*.timer Check service executable permissions
